text: The Scheldt is a 435-kilometre-long (270 mi) river that flows through northern France, western Belgium, and the southwestern part of the Netherlands, into the North Sea. In French, the river is called Escaut, in Dutch and in German, it is called Schelde. Its latin name is Scaldis.The Scheldt is an important waterway. Boats can get up to Cambrai. From there they can get on to the Canal de Saint-Quentin. The Scheldtâ€“Rhine Canal connects it to the Rhine. ==References== Category:Rivers of France Category:Rivers of Belgium Category:Rivers of the Netherlands Category:1520s disestablishments Category:16th-century disestablishments in Germany
title: Scheldt
